sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Here are our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The toughest sanctions yet. EU countries agree to cut Russian oil imports by 90% until the end of the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The biggest gains yet. Russian troops now control half of the strategic Donbass city of Severodonetsk in eastern Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Severodonetsk in eastern Ukraine. In the Cube, we take a look at the pain Shanghai has had to endure as authorities announce an end to its eight-week COVID lockdown. And from the channel to the Riviera, a group of cyclists cross France in 10 days to raise money for Ukrainian aid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: aid. Welcome to the program. I'm Stefan Grobe. The European Union has agreed to a partial ban of Russian oil imports as leaders in Brussels finally reached a compromise deal with Hungary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Finalizing the long-awaited sixth round of sanctions against Moscow, the EU will immediately block Russian oil arrivals to its ports, which represents over two-thirds of total imports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The 27-member state bloc aims to cut all Russian oil by 90% by the end of the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The agreement was made amid fierce resistance from Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who said an embargo would destroy his country's economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen praised the move as an important step forward.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And speaking on Tuesday, she outlined plans to end Europe's dependency on all Russian fossil fuels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: You might remember that in Versailles, the leaders decided to phase out the dependency on Russian fossil fuels as soon as possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We started with coal. Yesterday, in the middle of the night, we decided then to have a ban now on de facto 90% of manage and what is the roadmap to really get rid of the dependency of Russian fossil fuels and here with view to gas? The answer is repower EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: the two-day summit in Brussels for us. Good evening, Maeve. Great to see you. So the reason it took so long to pass the oil embargo was primarily Hungarian opposition. How did the Orban government finally get on board? Good question, Stefan. We've been reporting about this Hungarian opposition for the past couple of weeks with Viktor Orban, the Hungarian Prime Minister dragging his heels on this proposal and with the European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen even traveling to Budapest a couple of weeks ago to try and get him on board but to no avail because the reason you're hearing about unity and a big announcement from Brussels today on that sixth sanction package and a de facto Russian oil embargo is because the EU leaders gave in to the demands of the Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and essentially Hungary is exempt from this embargo.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And we've seen tonight Viktor Orban, the Hungarian Prime Minister, take to social media, take to his Facebook to express his satisfaction.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He said Brussels' victory for Hungary, he said, we are exempt.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now, we heard from leaders tonight and from the heads of the institutions that they will revisit this Hungarian exemption over the next couple of weeks, according to the Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, as soon as the 23rd and the 24th of June, when EU leaders meet here again for an EU summit in Brussels. It's also worth pointing out, Stefan, that Hungary was not the only country to object and oppose this embargo, even though they were the most forceful in their opposition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Countries like Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Bulgaria also expressed concerns about their interests, of course, but they were given some concessions too. Also worth pointing out that just last night we saw President Zelensky of Ukraine join EU leaders via a video link calling for unity, saying that unity was Europe's strength and squabbles and internal disputes just was a gift for Vladimir Putin, the Russian president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Banning Russian oil is one thing, but banning the more important Russian gas is much trickier. Are there any plans in the pipeline, if I might say, to do exactly that? Absolutely not. That's a totally different discussion, Stefan. For weeks, diplomats have been telling us that's not on the table for now. They're not even close.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And EU leaders reiterated that point as well today. That would just be too much for the European economy to hold. We're hearing that it could be potentially next year or the year after. It's off the table for now. But what Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, is putting on the table today was her Repower Europe proposal with 300 billion euros that would focus on trying to wean this continent off their dependency on Russian fossil fuels, starting with coal, now gradually moving to oil, and then one day on to gas. She said she's focusing now on diversification, also on sourcing from more reliable partners. She said the European Commission have a task force now in place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They've been working and meeting with other partners since January, and now that work is all gradually starting to pay off.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: All right, Maeve McMahon in Brussels, thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Let's hear about the Russian perspective now and for that I'm joined by our correspondent Galina

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.sentence: Russia if this oil embargo takes into action could lose and it could reduce Russia's most lucrative export revenue.

sentences.sentence: Bloomberg's estimations show that we could talk about 20 billion euros per year loss of this amount an analyst quoted by the russian state agency tas said that the loss could be twice smaller but still we are talking about huge budget losses and the revenue for from oil uh selling is about a third of a russian budget and the eu here plays a huge role just in 2021 Russia produced approximately 520 millions tons of oil and 110 went to the European Union so we're talking at least about 20 percent of Russia's oil revenues Russian officials right now are saying that it is europe which will lose and not russia that russia will try clients abroad will turn to the east to china for example but i've spoken with mihail krutikhin a russian oil and gas analyst and he told me that this is not that easy and he also said that this embargo could be a huge blow for the Russian oil industry.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

And even if there is demand it is sure that those new clients will ask for huge discounts which is the case of India right now.

POCHROV, RAILWAY STATION, AND THE ELDERLY AS WELL AS YOUNG FAMILIES BOARD TRAINS TO ESCAPE THEIR HOMES IN DONETSK.

sentences.sentence: They've hung on to their homes and possessions since the invasion in late February. They'll start June, both old and young, with fear and uncertainty.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Sasha Vakulina now joins me for more on the latest in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

And we've heard about two Russian soldiers being sentenced for war crimes in Ukraine what do we know about them?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So this is what we know Ukrainian court did sentence two captured Russian soldiers to more than 11 years in jail each for shelling a civilian area in the country's east amid Moscow's offensive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

That's according to the country's prosecutor general. I have to say that Kyiv pays particular attention to this persecution and to identifying the alleged war crimes and also to taking them to the court. And today, Estonia, Latvia and Slovakia also decided to join international investigation team in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Inflation is soaring in Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: According to some, the situation could deteriorate further in the coming months. And that could potentially increase the gap between rich and poorer nations. Mark Armstrong has more. Inflation is continuing to soar across Europe, including in the leading economies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Germany's annual rate hit 7.9% in May, according to official figures, the country's highest level in almost 50 years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The main culprit is energy prices, that have risen by 38% year on year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But the Federal Office of Statistics says food prices in the Eurozone's largest economy are also up by 11.1%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The office also says Germans' earnings are down by 1.8% in real terms compared to a year ago. The latest report from the International Labour Organization says people are being hit by multiple new and interconnected global crises. As well as inflation, they include supply issues, financial turbulence and the war in Ukraine, all of which is hitting people's pockets hard.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We talk about the need to protect, as you would expect, the most vulnerable, those in most difficulty, the need for social protection to be factored into the way governments are responding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're arguing for dialogue, bringing together governments, employers and workers to find acceptable solutions in situations which are undoubtedly very difficult, that adds to the legitimacy and acceptability of solutions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And the bad news is there's little sign of a situation improving any time soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In fact, the ILO says things could deteriorate further in the coming months, increasing the gap between the rich and the poorer nations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The ILO says it's seeing a continuation of what it calls the great divergence in recovery trajectories between different income groups and that, says the organization, is something that should concern us all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: China's commercial hub will cast off most of its coronavirus restrictions with things like public transport reopening and people being allowed to leave their residencies without a special pass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Now, as you can see from this graph, cases peaked around mid to late April and have fallen significantly since then. But it hasn't been an easy road to get here. As you can see from this video, draconian measures were implemented.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Whole quarters were sealed off. People found it difficult to get food and even some medical supplies. And this led to sometimes desperate scenes occurring. As you can see here, when back in April, residents of a building were told that part of their block would be used to house COVID patients, men in hazmat suits turned up with the word police written on them. People were dragged away, people were arrested. And it brings us to the wider point that this lockdown was extremely painful for people who had to self-isolate, but also people who lost their businesses and for the country as a whole.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Shanghai is China's economic powerhouse.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The lockdown is now over, but there's a fundamental problem of keeping zero COVID policies in a world that's increasingly learning to live with the virus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: zero COVID policies in a world that's increasingly learning to live with the virus. A study from Shanghai's Fudan University showed that if zero COVID policies were jettisoned, around 1.6 million deaths would occur. And that's quite difficult, even though most of the world is doing this for the Chinese Communist Party, Stefan, because they have increasingly said that this is a reason why they're better than the West. They haven't had many COVID deaths. And this is why the Chinese Communist Party, Stefan, because they have increasingly said that this is a reason why they're better than the West.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They haven't had many COVID deaths, and this is why the Chinese approach is better, which means it's a difficult option to try and jettison it.

sentences.sentence: UK's Home Secretary Priti Patel is set to decide on whether to extradite WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The documents revealed potential crimes committed by the U.S. in Iraq and Afghanistan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Human rights organizations have protested the possible move, arguing that it could represent a threat to press freedom globally.

sentences.sentence: MP John Stevenson said that he was deeply disappointed in the illegal parties during the COVID-19 lockdown that were outlined in a report published last week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It has taken 10 consecutive days of exhausting cycling from the south of England to the south of France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: A group of cyclists brave the elements and some challenging routes, all in aid of humanitarian efforts in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Andy Rubini reports. A team of nine cyclists led by former professional footballer Silva Dista has completed a gruelling 1,300-kilometre trek from Sandbanks in Dorset to Saint-Tropez in the south of France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The epic ride was entirely self-funded, with all donations going towards the Ukraine humanitarian appeal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: going towards the Ukraine's humanitarian appeal.

sentences.sentence: We're not going to change the world, but we know that it will bring some peace and comfort to some families.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
